Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: A11y_NuGet Service_Organizations_Email Notifications_HighContrast: In High contrast mode Keyboard focus is not completely visible on "Check boxes"." (#8924) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

Source: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1437973

### Repro Steps

1. Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/ 
1. Tab navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
1. Tab navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
1. Tab navigate to ‚ÄúManage Organizations‚Äù from the Profile Dropdown and hit enter.
1. Tab navigate to "Add New" control and hit enter.
1. Enter values in "Organization Name" and "Organization Email Address" and hit enter on "Add" Control.
1. Tab navigate to ‚ÄúManage Organizations‚Äù from the Profile Dropdown and hit enter.
1. "Organizations" screen gets opened.
1. Turn ON High Contrast mode and verify that all the elements of "Email Notifications" and check keyboard focus is completely visible or no "check boxes" in high contrast mode.

In High contrast mode keyboard focus is not completely visible on "check boxes" when we navigate using keyboard.

Note: This issue is also reproducing in select scope check box in API keys.

### Expected Behavior

The Keyboard focus should be completely visible on "Check boxes" when we navigate using keyboard.


### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Feature]: Show and score packages based on popularity, quality, maintenance, and community." (#8964) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Related Problem

_No response_

### The Elevator Pitch

With over 290,000 unique NuGet packages and over 4,000,000 package versions available to download, developers face an even harder challenge of being able to validate the quality of a package to be used in their projects.

There's many challenges to the quality of a package such as how many dependencies the package takes on, the amount of downloads the package has, and being maintained by a large company to name a few.

NuGet has many different types of packages such as frameworks, dependencies, tools, templates, and many more. With each package, there is metadata & package contents that are used to help define the overall package.

A high quality or "healthy" package is one that follows the following characteristics:

- **It is actively maintained.** Either with recent commits or an annual update/notice that the package is up-to-date.
- **It is documented.** It provides enough documentation to install, get started, and has public API documentation on it's members.
- **It has a way to report bugs.** It provides a centralized location or repository in which issues are regularly triaged & resolved in future releases.
- **It resolves security flaws quickly.** It fixes known vulnerabilities & releases an unaffected release quickly.
- **It is not deprecated.** It is in an active state meeting all the criteria above.

This is a small list of the many different characteristics that may make a package of high quality or "healthy".

Having packages of high quality that depend on other packages of high quality will make the overall software supply chain of higher quality and thus more secure & reliable for those using .NET tooling.

This proposal introduces the concept known as Package Scoring or NET Score for short.

TL;DR packages have a combined score of four categories that helps developers make trust decisions. Those categories might be:

- Popularity- How popular a package is & recognized in the ecosystem.
- Quality - The completeness of a package following best practices & providing documentation.
- Maintenance - The state of maintenance & free of security vulnerabilities.
- Community - The sustainability of an active community for the package.

https://github.com/dotnet/designs/pull/216

### Additional Context and Details

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Incorrect link on NuGet TOU page" (#8963) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: The NuGet TOU page (https://www.nuget.org/policies/Terms) and noticed that the link in the ‚ÄúYour Privacy‚Äù section to the Microsoft Privacy Statement is wrong. The current link (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2180118) points to the ‚ÄúReporting Infringement‚Äù page. It should it point to the Privacy Policy page (https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=521839) that‚Äôs in the footer instead. Confirmed with CELA.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Create artifacts for sharing NuGetGallery.Services" (#8962) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
I did a feasibility spike on getting this project's artifacts into a nupkg for broader use, and got it working using a nupkg stub workaround with built assets (the same approach used for the jobs projects in the same buildstep).

Note that using the `New-ProjectPackage` PS function for this was a dead end, as this project is not SDK-style (the projects in the repo that do use this function are all SDK-style). The msbuild error there is that the `path` target is not defined, and this target comes built in to SDK-style projects. Converting the Services project into an SDK-style project is also non-trivial as it turns out, so that can possibly be future work.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Implement If-Modified-Since or Etag cache for NuGet.Client" (#11529) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
While looking into [this](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/8352) performance bug I noticed we're wasting so much time just downloading json and deserializing it. Some of those files are 300-400MB size for MS some internal projects. We need some way to know just content changed or not without having to download whole json response. We can either use `If-Modified-Since` or `Etag` cache.
 
Related issues:
https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/8048
https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/1399

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remove repeated/redundant reading of v3-index.json file" (#11341) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: From https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/11341 issue I noticed this. Currently `dotnet restore` command trigger about 16x reading of v3-index.json file in http cache, for dotnet `build` about 80x according to ETL trace. Even though file is small, we better to read only once, because it's on hot path and IO operations are quite expensive.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: ContentItemCollections.FindItems should not be obsolete as its implementation no longer uses yield returns" (#11487) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

6.0.0.163

### Worked before?

N/A

### Impact

Other

### Repro Steps & Context

This PR addresses overallocation of enumerators through the FindItemsImplementation: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/4099

Since FindItemsImplementation was fixed to no longer use yield returns, and the FindItems public method delegates to this method does not need to be obsolete and the obsolete attribute should be removed.

### Verbose Logs

_No response_
